p: In turn, urban rivers and streams with wide (>30 m) riparian zones, but free of woody alien vegetation, provide sunny microhabitat and promote habitat heterogeneity ( Figure 2). These green corridors buffer urban impacts and are attractive breeding sites for some dragonflies. Dragonfly assemblages recover remarkably well when alien vegetation is cleared, and some endemic species recover their area of occupancy and part of their former distribution ranges [ 70]. Artificial wetlands in urban areas initially attract only common and widespread dragonfly species, but they may also attract rare and localized species once native vegetation has had enough time to establish [ 71].
